questions.question_text: An organization has configured Auto Scaling with ELB. One of the instance health check returns the status as Impaired to Auto Scaling. What will Auto Scaling do in this scenario?

choices.D: Notify ELB to stop sending traffic to the impaired instance
choices.C: Notify the user using SNS for the failed state
choices.B: Terminate the instance and launch a new instance
choices.A: Perform a health check until cool down before declaring that the instance has failed

questions.answer_description: The Auto Scaling group determines the health state of each instance periodically by checking the results of the Amazon EC2 instance status checks. If the instance status description shows any other state other than ג€runningג€ or the system status description shows impaired, Auto Scaling considers the instance to be unhealthy. Thus, it terminates the instance and launches a replacement.

discussion.content: B. Terminate the instance and launch a new instance

Selected Answer: D
Auto Scaling will notify the ELB to stop sending traffic to the impaired instance, allowing the organization to focus on troubleshooting and resolving the issue with the instance without impacting the overall availability and performance of the application.

questions.question_text:
A user is using Cloudformation to launch an EC2 instance and then configure an application after the instance is launched. The user wants the stack creation of
ELB and AutoScaling to wait until the EC2 instance is launched and configured properly. How can the user configure this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
MyWaitCondition:
 Type: AWS::CloudFormation::WaitCondition
 Properties:
 Handle: !Ref EC2Instance
 Timeout: <desired_timeout>
D. The user can use the WaitCondition resource to hold the creation of the other dependent resources

questions.answer_description:
AWS Cloudformation is an application management tool which provides application modelling, deployment, configuration, management and related activities.
AWS CloudFormation provides a WaitCondition resource which acts as a barrier and blocks the creation of other resources until a completion signal is received from an external source, such as a user application or management system.

choices.C: The user can use the DependentCondition resource to hold the creation of the other dependent resources
choices.A: It is not possible that the stack creation will wait until one service is created and launched
choices.B: The user can use the HoldCondition resource to wait for the creation of the other dependent resources
choices.D: The user can use the WaitCondition resource to hold the creation of the other dependent resources

choices.A: Run the command as-join-auto-scaling-group to join the two groups
choices.C: Run the command as-copy-auto-scaling-group to join the two groups
choices.D: Run the command as-merge-auto-scaling-group to merge the groups

questions.question_text: An organization has configured two single availability zones. The Auto Scaling groups are configured in separate zones. The user wants to merge the groups such that one group spans across multiple zones. How can the user configure this?
questions.answer_description: If the user has configured two separate single availability zone Auto Scaling groups and wants to merge them then he should update one of the groups and delete the other one. While updating the first group it is recommended that the user should increase the size of the minimum, maximum and desired capacity as a summation of both the groups.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/autoscaling/update-auto-scaling-group.html
Correct Answer: B
B. Run the command as-update-auto-scaling-group to configure one group to span across zones and delete the other group

questions.answer_description: AWS consolidated billing enables the organization to consolidate payments for multiple Amazon Web Services (AWS. accounts within a single organization by making a single paying account. To add a particular account (linked) to the master (payee) account, the payee account has to request the linked account to join consolidated billing. Once the linked account accepts the request henceforth all charges incurred by the linked account will be paid by the payee account.

choices.A: The payee account has to request AWS support to link the other accounts with his account
choices.D: The owner of the linked account requests the payee account to add his account to consolidated billing
choices.C: The payee account will send a request to the linked account to be a part of consolidated billing
choices.B: The owner of the linked account should add the payee account to his master account list from the billing console

questions.question_text: An AWS account wants to be part of the consolidated billing of his organization's payee account. How can the owner of that account achieve this?

discussion.content: C is the correct answer.
Correct Answer: C
C. The payee account will send a request to the linked account to be a part of consolidated billing

discussion.content:
Answer is ACD: You use different types of security credentials depending on how you interact with AWS. For example, you use a user name and password to sign in to the AWS Management Console. You use access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS API actions.

Key pairs consist of a public key and a private key. You use the private key to create a digital signature, and then AWS uses the corresponding public key to validate the signature. You can create Amazon EC2 key pairs from the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API.

Access keys consist of an access key ID and a secret access key. You use access keys to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS if you use the AWS SDKs, REST, or Query APIs.

One can use the IAM API to upload a certificate, via the UploadServerCertificate request.

Option B and E are wrong because this is done via the Console and not via API’s.

For more information on Security, please visit the below URL:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-sec-cred-types.html

CDE are correct. 
While options A (Key pairs) and B (Console passwords) are also related to AWS access, they are not as directly relevant to API access credentials. Key pairs are more commonly used for SSH access to EC2 instances, and Console passwords are used to access the AWS Management Console. While they are essential for overall security, they are not the primary credentials used for making programmatic API requests, which are the focus of the question. Hence, options C, D, and E are the more relevant credentials to evaluate in the context of AWS API access.
